The classification ol obligations according to the mode in which they originate meets us in Bk. iii. 13· a, and is spoken of in the notes to that passage3 another division, ot great prominence in Roman law, requires some explanation. An obligation is none the less an obligation merely because the creditor is unable to enforce it by action; there are other modes in which the duty may be dis· charged besides this, so that the relation sails only in one ol its most ordinary incidents. Actionability is only one ol such usual incidents, though perhaps the most characteristic ol all, and an obligatio does not lose its legal character by reason oi its absence only. Such non-actionable obligations are said to be ‘natural’ in contrast with those which are ‘civit' i.e. enlorceable by action ; in Dig. 46. 3. 95. 4, the hond is called vinculum aequitatis, as being imposed by equity, though the precise relation ol the ‘natiue’ implied in a natural obligation, and the nature whose law is identified by the jurists with equity and the ius gentium, is somewhat obscure. That the jural recognition of such obligations originated in the ius gentium seems to be affirmed in Dig. 50. 17. 84. 1 ‘is natura debet, quem iure gentium dare oportet, cuius fidem secuti sumus,' though by some writers it is ascribed to natural law in a philosophical rather than a legal sense.
